Situation1: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: I woke up early, determined to make the most of my day off by attending the national continuing education webinar for pharmacists. It was mandatory for my license renewal, and I knew I needed to stay updated on the latest treatments. As I set up my laptop, the local news blared a heat advisory. I remembered Mrs. Lee, my elderly neighbor who lived alone on our floor. She struggled with the heat and sometimes forgot to drink enough water. As a citizen, I felt a responsibility to check on her, especially with the city urging everyone to look out for vulnerable neighbors during emergencies. But the webinar was about to start, and missing it could mean falling behind professionally. My phone buzzed with a reminder for the session, while outside, the sun was already beating down. I stood in the hallway, torn between my duty to my profession and my responsibility as a member of my community, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
